metadata.case_name: Petition Nos. 88 and 106 of 1957 and 103 of 1959
metadata.case_number: Original Jurisdiction Petitions Nos. 88 and 106 of 1957 and 103 of 1959

facts.text: Petition No. 88 of 1957 by a cotton textiles manufacturing company in Ahmedabad. Machinery installed in 1893 and never replaced. Factory became uneconomic unit, closed on April 27, 1957 after notice in March 1957. Company incurring losses year after year. Early 1956, Registrar of Companies, Bombay requested Central Government to authorize winding up, but authority not given. Factory continued till April 28, 1957.

Petition No. 106 of 1957 by petitioner running a coal mine purchased in November 1953. Large investments made, but due to flooding by underground water, consistent losses aggregating over Rs. 7 lakhs by February 1957. Decided to close mine, gave notice to employees, paid one month's salary to monthly paid staff and 15 days wages to weekly/daily rated staff. Closed on February 10, 1957.

Petition No. 103 of 1959 by company owning spinning and weaving factory at Jamnagar started in 1938. Proved uneconomic, persistent losses aggregating Rs. 28 lakhs by end of 1957. Weaving department closed February 1, 1957, entire factory closed April 24, 1957 after notice to employees.

Industrial Disputes Act amended by Act 43 of 1953 incorporating Ch. VA (ss. 25A-25J) providing compensation for lay-off and retrenchment. S.25F requires notice and compensation for retrenchment. Retrenchment defined in s.2(oo) as termination otherwise than punishment.
In Hariprasad Shivshankar Shukla v. A.D. Divekar decided 27-11-1956, Supreme Court held retrenchment does not include termination on bona fide closure.

President promulgated Ordinance No. IV of 1957 on April 27, 1957 amending Ch. VA retrospectively from Dec 1, 1956 for compensation on closure/transfer. Replaced by Act 18 of 1957 effective June 6, 1957 retrospectively from Nov 28, 1956 incorporating s.25FFF.
After Hariprasad judgment, number of undertakings closed, >25,000 workmen unemployed.

S.25FFF(1) entitles workmen with 1 year continuous service to notice and compensation per s.25F on closure. Proviso limits max to 3 months average pay if closure due to circumstances beyond employer's control. Explanation: financial difficulties/losses/undisposed stocks not deemed unavoidable circumstances beyond control.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.25FFF(1) of Industrial Disputes Act imposes unreasonable restrictions on freedom to carry on business under Art.19(1)(g), including right to close business, due to liability for compensation even on bona fide closure beyond control, retrospective operation, standardized rates unrelated to loss or capacity to pay.
Whether s.25FFF(1) discriminates between employers under Art.14 by distinguishing closures before/after Nov 27, 1956.
Whether s.25FFF(1) violates Art.20 by penalising acts (closures) which were not offences when committed.
Whether explanation to proviso of s.25FFF(1) is unreasonable by excluding financial difficulties/losses/stocks from unavoidable circumstances.

petitioner_arguments.text: S.25FFF(1) imposes unreasonable restriction on Art.19(1)(g) as compensation is condition precedent to closure even if bona fide and beyond control; retrospective; not related to employee loss but standardized; ignores employer capacity.
Discriminates between employers in same circumstances under Art.14.
Penalises past closures not offences when committed, violating Art.20.
Explanation to proviso unreasonable as financial losses etc. not unavoidable beyond control.

court_reasoning.text: S.25FFF(1) does not make payment condition precedent to closure; merely creates liability for notice/compensation post-closure as if retrenched; distinguishes from s.25F prohibition on retrenchment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Right to notice/compensation flows from closure, not vice versa.

court_reasoning.text: Restriction reasonable under Art.19(6) in interest of general public to redress unemployment misery; similar to retrenchment compensation to soften hardship.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Loss of service due to closure same as retrenchment; social justice basis.

court_reasoning.text: Standardized compensation related to service length reasonable; accounts for experience/seniority lost; standardization efficient for large numbers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not unreasonable despite no judicial assessment per case.

court_reasoning.text: Capacity to pay irrelevant post-closure; recovery from assets; proviso limits to 3 months if beyond control.
court_reasoning.key_observation: For running business, capacity matters; not for closed.

court_reasoning.text: Explanation does not preclude tribunal considering if financial issues combined with others make unavoidable; only 'merely' financial not beyond control.
No Art.14 violation; law applies prospectively from fixed date; distinction between pre/post date transactions not discrimination.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art.14 strikes at unequal application to similarly circumstanced persons, not temporal differentiation.

court_reasoning.text: No Art.20 violation; creates civil liability, not penal; no prohibition/mandate breached; s.31(2) inapplicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Failure to pay civil liability not offence unless specified.

holdings.text: S.25FFF(1) including proviso and explanation imposes reasonable restrictions under Art.19(6); does not violate Arts.14 or 20.
No discrimination under Art.14 by retrospective civil liability from fixed date.
No violation of Art.20 as civil not penal liability.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hariprasad Shivshankar Shukla v. A.D. Divekar
precedents_cited.relevance: Held retrenchment excludes closure; prompted legislation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen
Mohd. Hanif Quareshi v. The State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Reasonableness judged in interest of general public, not individual irksomeness.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bijay Cotton Mills Ltd. v. The State of Ajmer
precedents_cited.relevance: Individual economic difficulties no ground to strike down law.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Imposes compensation liability on closure treated as retrenchment; recoverable as land revenue arrears.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitions under Art.32; s.25FFF upheld against challenges under Arts.19,14,20.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879
statutes_cited.relevance: Mode of recovery as arrears; imprisonment possible for land revenue default, but civil liability.

outcome.summary: Petitions challenging constitutionality of s.25FFF(1) of Industrial Disputes Act dismissed. Section held valid, not violating Arts.14,19,20. Petitions fail with costs.

key_quotes.text: "The word retrenchment as defined in s. 2(oo) ... do not include termination of services of all workmen on a bona fide closure of industry".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Haripadas case, basis for legislation.

key_quotes.text: "retirement compensation was intended to give the workmen some relief and to soften the rigour of hardship which retrenchment brings".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies purpose of compensation for social justice.

key_quotes.text: "Whether ... reasonable restriction ... must be adjudged not in the background of any theoretical standards ... but in the light of the nature ... of the right".
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the impugned s. 25FFF(1) including the proviso and the explanation thereto are not unconstitutional".
key_quotes.speaker: court
